message.content:
We can “build up” the final balance‐sheet “assets” by starting with the “Initial” asset entries and then adding the net effect of the operating transactions (that is, the “profit” earned from sales plus “other asset increases” such as accrued interest, while “non‑cash” (non–profit) expenses such as operating (and financial) expenses and depreciation reduce net profit). (In a full “accounting‐journal” solution the many purchase entries are “asset‐for‐asset” exchanges so do not change total assets.) 

In our “new problem” the following was done step‐by‐step.

Step 1. Sum the three “Initial” lines:
  Cash deposit = 3,000,000.00 
  Bank deposit = 5,000,000.00 
  Fixed Assets = 5,000,000.00 
  → Total initial assets = 3,000,000 + 5,000,000 + 5,000,000 = 13,000,000.00

Step 2. From all the “Sale” transactions each record shows a “profit” amount (that is, the operating gain on that sale). In our new table the sale records (by id) are as follows with profit (all figures given to two decimals in our final tally):

• Sale20240102001: 184230.98 
• Sale20240102002: 174894.93 
• Sale20240103004: 187021.71 
• Sale20240106006: 80661.23 
• Sale20240107008: 1041.74 
• Sale20240108010: 185922.71 
• Sale20240110012: 925.47 
• Sale20240110013: 195859.81 
• Sale20240111015: 1212.39 
• Sale20240111016: 177286.94 
• Sale20240111017: 93204.06 
• Sale20240112018: 8759.13 
• Sale20240123031: 1384.14 
• Sale20240128037: 141259.43 
• Sale20240128038: 164938.80 
• Sale20240130040: 116405.22 
• Sale20240130041: 172245.21 
• Sale20240130042: 1313.08 
• Sale20240131044: 141168.27 
• Sale20240131045: 1255.80 
• Sale20240204049: 6896.81 
• Sale20240205052: 21527.91 

When these “profit” column values are summed the gross “sales‐profit total” is about:  
  2,059,415.77

Step 3. In a “proper” income statement the non‑sales operating costs (for example the many “Expense” transactions – including sales expenses, administrative expenses and also “Financial Expenses”) are deducted. When we add up (by careful grouping) all the expense entries (note that we do not include depreciation and we do not “adjust” for purchases – which are simply asset‐to‐asset movements) we obtain a total expense of about:  
  645,258.91

Step 4. Thus the operating “net profit” (before adjustment for certain “accrual” items) is 
  2,059,415.77 – 645,258.91 = 1,414,156.86

Step 5. In addition the “Interest Receivables” records (each of which is an asset increase) add up to about:  
  14,796.43

Step 6. Also, two “Depreciation” postings (which lower the book‐value of fixed assets) total about:  
  45,747.38 + 45,744.93 = 91,492.31

Step 7. Then the net “addition” to the retained earnings (and so to total assets) is  
  (net profit + interest receivable) – depreciation  
    = (1,414,156.86 + 14,796.43) – 91,492.31  
    ≈ 1,428,953.29 – 91,492.31  
    ≈ 1,337,460.98

Step 8. Finally, the “final” total assets (which in a balance‐sheet “asset” line will include the initial balance plus any net positive change in retained earnings) become  
  13,000,000.00 + 1,337,460.98 = 14,337,460.98

(There is no net change coming from the “Purchase” entries because—by assumption—they are recorded as increases in one asset account (inventory or fixed assets) and a decrease in another asset (cash or payable) so that the total remains the same.)

Thus the answer is:

Total Assets Initial Value = 13,000,000.00  
Total Assets End Value = 14,337,460.98

Below is the answer in the requested JSON format.

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Total Assets Initial Value": "13000000.00", "Total Assets End Value": "14337460.98"} }
``` 

Note:
• The solution is reached by “netting” the operating gains (the sale profit sums minus the cash/operational expenses), then adding accrued interest receivables while subtracting the depreciation charge. 
• Purchases do not change total assets since they merely convert one asset item into another.

This is one acceptable interpretation of the many‐step calculation based on the given entries.
